Rare earth modified RuOx-MgAl-layered double oxides as efficient dual catalysts for direct maleinisation of linoleic acid Tengfei Niu a ⁎ Zhijia Chen a Ting Han a Mingyuan Zhang a Lingjiang Deng a Hongyan Miao a Yuqin Jiang b Bangqing Ni a a Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, China Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University Wuxi 214122 China Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, P. R. China b Henan Engineering Research Centre of Chiral Hydroxyl Pharmaceutical, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang 453007, China Henan Engineering Research Centre of Chiral Hydroxyl Pharmaceutical, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Normal University Xinxiang 453007 China Henan Engineering Research Centre of Chiral Hydroxyl Pharmaceutical, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang 453007, China ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of rare earth elements (Y, La, and Ce) modified Ru doped MgAl-layered double oxides (LDO) have been prepared and applied in direct maleinisation of linoleic acid. The as-obtained catalysts can promote both isomerization reaction and Diels-Alder reaction in one-pot to generate 22-carbon cyclic succinic anhydrides (C22-CSA) efficiently. Among the surveyed LDO, Y modified Ru doped LDO (RuOx-Y-LDO) showed the best yield (93 %) and the turnover frequency (TOF) is higher than that of previously reported catalysts. Characterizations and control experiments verified that Y elements endow the LDO with stronger basic site densities to chelate with carboxyl group of oleic acid, resulted in smaller particle size of Ru and strong Ru-support interaction to isomerization of linoleic acid. The Y cation in RuOx-LDO could rich Lewis acid and significantly promoted the Diels-Alder reaction. Furthermore, RuOx-Y-LDO catalyst could be used up to 20 times without a significant loss in its catalytic activity. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Rare earth MgAl-layered double oxides (LDO) RuO2-LDO, dual catalyst Maleinisation of linoleic acid C22-CSA Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction During the last decades, the utilization of green and degradable chemicals derived from renewable resources as alternatives to petrochemical products has received considerable attention in chemical industry [1–3]. In this context, plant oils have been considered as promising resources of renewable feedstocks, since fine chemicals, monomers and polymers can be obtained from these resources [4–6]. Unsaturated fatty acids such as oleic acid, linoleic acid and linolenic acid are main component of plant oil, which can be used to prepare high value-added chemicals. For example, hydrogenation of unsaturated fatty acids gives saturated fatty acids, which are used for the production of surfactants [7–9]. Epoxidized unsaturated fatty acid derivatives are used as plasticizers and stabilizers in plastics as well as for the synthesis of epoxy resins [10–14]. The oxidative cleavage of the CC bond in unsaturated fatty acids could produce dicarboxylic acids, which are often used for the manufacture of bio-based polymers [15–19]. The isomerization of linoleic acid to generates conjugated linoleic acid (CLA), which has been shown special physiological activities and has been widely used in medicine, food, health products, cosmetics and other fields [20–23]. Recently, the maleinisation of unsaturated fatty acid to generate 22-carbon cyclic succinic anhydrides (C22-CSA) has been gained significant research interest [24–27]. C22-CSA with special structure possesses a wide range of applications in lubricating oil, resin additive, corrosion inhibitor, printing ink, green surfactant, cutting fluid and so on. The development of catalytic processes with high performance is recognized as an effective way for the transformation of unsaturated fatty acid to C22-CSA. Traditional methods for the maleinisation of unsaturated fatty acids involve following two steps: alkali isomerization of linoleic acid to generate CLA and Diels-Alder reaction between CLA and maleic anhydride ( Scheme 1a) [28,29]. This method usually need the addition of excess strong alkali such as potassium hydroxide, accompanied by difficulties of CLA separation. Thus, an alkali-free protocol for direct maleinisation of linoleic acid is highly desirable. Recently, iodine catalyzed one-pot sequential isomerization of linoleic acid and Diels–Alder reaction with maleic anhydride (MA) to form C22-CSA was reported (Scheme 1b). However, the iodine catalyst could not be reused after the reaction [30]. Alternatively, monounsaturated fatty acids also could reacted with a dienophile to generate C22-CSA derivatives with homogeneous rhodium catalysts (Scheme 1c). However, such catalysis results in lots of acyclic maleinated byproducts [31,32]. Thus, the development of efficientand heterogeneous catalysis system for isomerization of linoleic acid while promote the Diels-Alder reaction in one-pot is still a challenge. For the isomerization of linoleic acid, various of heterogeneous catalysts such as Pd, Ni, Pt, Rh, Pt–Rh, Ir, and Os immobilized on various supports have been reported [33–39]. However, these catalytic processes utilized hydrogen to generate half hydrogenated intermediates, accompanied by unwanted hydrogenated by-products. Recently, Ru based heterogeneous catalyst such as Ru/USY [40], Ru-Ba-MgZrO2 [41], Ru-MgAl [42], Ru/MWCNTs [43], Ru/Al2O3 [44] and Ru–Ni/NaY [45] have been developed for hydrogen-free isomerization of linoleic acid. Nonetheless, these catalysts are usually suffered from the drawbacks of low CLA production rate. Meanwhile, it also cannot promote the Diels–Alder cycloadditions of CLA. Thus, the design of dual active site Ru-based heterogeneous catalyst for both isomerization and Diels-Alder reaction is the key issue for the one-pot direct maleinisation of unsaturated atty acid. Inspired by these contributions, we envision the introduction of rare earth into the RuO2-LDO to prepare rare earth modified RuOx-LDO dual catalyst. The introduction of rare earth not only provides rich alkaline sites, but also effectively enhances the interaction between noble metal centers and carriers. On the other hand, the addition of rare earth cations to LDO can rich Lewis acid sites and effectively promoted the Diels–Alder cycloadditions of CLA. Herein, we report the isomerization of linoleic acid followed by tandem Diels-Alder reaction in one-pot under solvent-free condition to generate C22-CSA in the presence of RuOx-Y-LDO composite (Scheme 1d). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were synthesized as follow: a solution containing 21 mmol of Magnesium Chloride hexahydrate, 7 mmol of anhydrous Aluminum Chloride and 1.5 wt % Ruthenium (III) Chloride (Ru content was calculated according to the mass fraction of the final catalyst) were added dropwise to the solution containing 32 mmol of anhydrous sodium carbonate with vigorous stirring. And 1 M sodium hydroxide solution was added to the system to maintain the pH= 10. Then the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL polytetrafluoroethylene liner, and aged at 80 °C overnight. The obtained solid product was washed with deionized water until no Cl- in the filtrate which was detected by AgNO3 aqueous then dried at 80 °C for 12 h, the product after drying was denoted as Ru-MgAl-LDH. After grinding through a 100-mesh sieve, the precursor was heated to 450 °C (5 °C/min) in air and calcined for 4 h, which was recorded as RuO2-LDO. The preparation methods of the catalysts modified by rare earth elements (La, Y, Ce) were same as above except that the corresponding rare earth salt was added to the precursor salt solution, and the obtained products were denoted as RuOx-REE-LDO (REE = La, Y, Ce). The content of rare earth elements is also calculated according to the mass fraction of the final catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of composite oxide were measured by using Cu Kα source (λ = 0.15406 nm) and at a scanning rate of 5°/min on a Bruker D8 diffractometer. Specific surface area (SBET) was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Pore size distribution was calculated by Barrett-Joiner-Halenda (BJH) method. Micropore surface areas and volumes were calculated by the t-plot method. The temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) experiments were performed a BELCAT-II analyzer, with the TCD detector. 200 mg sample was pretreated at 450 °C for 0.5 h in He, and then high-purity CO2 was adsorbed at 50 °C. Then, the catalyst was blown by He flow for another 1 h to eliminate the physical absorbed species. Finally, the CO2-TPD was carried out from 50 to 1000°C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The temperature-programmed reduction by H2 (H2-TPR) experimentswere performed on TP 5076 chemisorption detector. The sample was heated to 450 °C in He for 1 h and cooled to 50 °C. Subsequently, the temperature was raised from 50 °C to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under 10 % H2/He, and the TPR profile was recorded. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectroscopy analysis was performed on the FALA 2000104 Fourier Infrared Spectrometer. The sample was mixed with KBr and the scanning range was 400–4000 cm−1. The surface morphology of the catalyst was tested on an S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) from Hitachi, Japan, with an acceleration voltage of 2 KV and a current of 10 μA. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of selected LDO samples were taken on a FEI Talos F200s transmission electron microscope. X‐ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of samples were measured by using a monochromatic Al Kα X‐ray (hν= 1486.6 eV) as the excitation source on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, and the basic pressure is 5 × 10−7 mBar. CO-pulse experiment for determing the dispersity of Ru and its particle size on the catalyst was carried out on an automatic chemcial adsorption instrument (BelCAT-II, Japan) equipped with a Mass detector. 0.1000 g of a dried sample was charged into a quartz tube, and then heated to 1073 K in a 10 %H2/Ar stream at a rate of 10 K/min and maintained there for 10 min. Subsequently, the sample was cooled down to 323 K in an Ar stream. After obtaining a stable baseline of the mass signal of m/z = 28, 1 mL of 5 %CO/Ar was plused into the carrier gas of Ar with an interval of 3 min until the CO peak areas unchaged in the last three pulses. The structure of the product was determined by AVANCE Ⅲ HD nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer, and the 1 H NMR spectrum of the product was obtained under the condition of 400 MHz. MALDI SYNAPT MS mass spectrometer was used to detect the product by mass spectrometry. 2.3 Activity measurement 2.3.1 Isomerization of linoleic acid In a typical reaction, 40 mg of catalyst was fed into a pressure tube containing 1 mL 1 mol/L linoleic solvent (N-decane solution). Then the system was sealed after a three-minute nitrogen purging and heated to 180 °C for stirring. After 2 h of reaction, the catalyst was isolated by centrifugation and about 0.2 mL of supernatant was sampled and mixed with 3 mL of boron trifluoride-methanol solution (14 %) for esterification at 100 °C for 20 min. The esterified product was added to 4 mL of water and then extracted by 2 mL hexane 3 times. The hexane phase containing the esters of acid products and the internal standard was analysed by Agilent GC6890N with FID and capillary column (HP FFAP, 30 m × 0.32 mm, 0.25 µm). The isomerization rate was judged by gas chromatography, the conversion rate and selectivity were calculated by area normalization method. 2.3.2 One-pot sequential isomerization/maleinisation of linoleic acid In a typical experiment, 1.6 g catalyst, 20 g linoleic acid and 21 g (3eq) maleic anhydride were fed into a pressure tube, then the system was sealed after a three-minute nitrogen purging and heated to 180 °C for 10 h. At the end of reaction, the crude product was obtained after centrifugal separation of the catalyst. CSA products can be separated by flash chromatography (n-hexane: ethyl acetate=8:1) and characterized by NMR and mass spectrometry (Fig. S9-S11). TOF = n (LA converted)/n (Ru)/t (reaction time), ruthenium content is based by the result of ICP (Table S3). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The synthetic process for catalyst is illustrated in Scheme 2. Ru and the corresponding rare earth elements were doped into the system by co-precipitation process to generate the precursor, named Ru-REE-MgAl-hydrotalcite (Ru-REE-LDH, REE=La, Y, Ce). The desired catalyst RuOx-REE-LDO was fabricated by calcining Ru-REE-LDH in air. The crystalline structure of precursors, composite oxides and catalyst samples were evaluated by XRD measurements. As shown in Fig. 1a. five broad diffraction peaks at 2θ of 11.3°, 22.7°, 34.5°, 60.5°, and 61.7° can be indexed as the characteristic peaks of layered hydrotalcite [46]. The intensity of diffraction peak are decreased in all samples. This observation may be due to the replacement of Al3+ (0.53 nm) by rare earth elements (Ce3+ = 0.102 nm, La3+=0.103 nm, Y3+ =0.09 nm) [47] proving the successful entry of rare earth element particles in laminate structure. Fig. 1b exhibits the XRD patterns of the calcined catalyst. The characteristic peaks at 2θ of 35°, 43°, 64° have appeared in all samples, which can be assigned to the characteristic peaks of RuOx-MgAl(REE)O. Besides, only RuOx-Ce-LDO presents additional CeO2 diffraction in the sample after calcination. This result is consistent with the XRD results of the precursor [48]. The FT-IR spectra (Fig. S1) shows that the vibration of C-O stretches (1360 cm−1) was disappeared in the calcined product, as well as the calcined products modified by rare earth elements relative to Ru-LDH, indicating that the CO3 2- between the hydrotalcite layers was completely decomposed to composite oxides. The textural analysis of the mixed oxides is reported in Table 1. The specific surface area of REE doped samples except Ce were much higher than that of REE-free sample. This can be due to that the Y and La may enhanced the disorder degree of the hydrotalcite structure [49]. However, the CeO2 deposition on the surface leads to a lower surface area. Moreover, the presence of Y and La also could decrease the particle size of catalyst. The decreasing tendency was also appreciated for pore volume and pore diameter, indicating that the inserting of Y and La inserted into the hydrotalcite structure is likely to generate water and released CO2, which are beneficial for the formation of more pores during dehydroxylation and interlayer carbonate decomposition [50]. In addition, the CO chemisorption has been carried out to measure the active sites of the catalyst. The results showed that, the Ru dispersion of RuO2-LDO was about 20.7 %. However, when doping of rare earth Y, the Ru dispersion was reduced to 17.6 %. This may due to the addition of Y in LDO occupied the position of Ru on the catalyst surface. The structure and surface morphology of RuOx-REE-LDO were characterized by SEM. As can be seen in Fig. 2a-d, the calcinated composite oxides all retained the layered structure of the hydrotalcite precursor except RuOx-Ce-LDO, indicating that the Ce atom doping may destroy the structure into irregular fragments. The most regular layered structure appeared in RuOx-Y-LDO (Fig. 2d). It may be attributed to the enhanced interaction between the layers arising from the ruthenium-oxygen-magnesium bond. The lattice spacing distances observed in the HRTEM images of RuOx-Y-LDO is 0.236 nm (Fig. 2e-f), assignable to the (111) facets of metallic Mg-Al. No obvious metal clusters were appeared in all samples, indicating the evenly distribution of Ru and Y in catalysts. The elemental mapping images clearly demonstrate the homogenous distribution of O, Mg, Al, Y and Ru in RuOx-Y-LDO. The basicity of the linoleic acid isomerization catalyst is an important factor that affects its catalytic activity. [51,52] Fig. 3a shows the CO2-TPD profiles of RuOx-REE-LDO, and the ratio of each desorption peak of CO2 is shown in Table S1. As we can seen, the peak around 427 °C corresponding to the ‘‘weak’’ basic sites, which most likely are associated with hydroxyl groups - almost completely disappears from the profiles of all REE-modified samples. This may be due to the reduction of hydroxyl radicals caused by rare earth ions replacing Al3+ [53]. In contrast, RuOx-REE-LDO show much strong Lewis basic site Mg2+-O2- peak around 613 °C (03) and strong basic site O2- around 927 °C (04). Compared to the profile of RuO2-LDO, desorption peak position of doped catalysts both shifted to higher temperature. This observation indicates that the rare earth elements should play a significant role in enhancing the basicity of catalysts. It can be explained as follows: the high specific surface area should facilitates the exposure of active sites. In addition, more strong basic sites were observed on RuOx-Y-LDO and RuOx-La-LDO than RuOx-Ce-LDO. This can be attributed to the smaller crystallite size of RuOx-Y-LDO and RuOx-La-LDO. Generally, the decrease in MgAl-O particle size would increase the amount of low coordinated oxygen atoms [54]. And the oxygen atoms with low coordination were just most likely the Lewis basic sites of higher strength in mixed oxides. RuOx-Ce-LDO had the largest crystallite size among all samples (see Table 1), which can explain the difference in curves compared to Y and La. Combine the results of XRD and CO2-TPD, fewer Ce atoms’ entrance in the layer structure and larger size of crystals ultimately led to a less basic increase compared to the Y and La element-modified catalysts. However, the arge ionic radius of Ce3+ cannot be accommodated, or only scarcely, in the brucite-like sheets of LDOs correlated with the distortions in the hydrotalcite layers, resulting stronger basicity than that of RuO2-LDO [55]. In order to provide direct evidence for Lewis acid sites identifcation, pyridine-adsorbed IR spectra was performed. As shown in Fig. 3b, after introducing Y species into RuO2-LDO catalyst, a strong peak at 1590 cm−1, which is ascribed to typical Lewis acid sites [56], is observed obviously increases in RuOx-Y-LDO catalyst. Relatively, the bands at 1490 cm−1, which is ascribed to typical Brønsted acid sites [56], exhibits a much lower intensity in both RuO2-LDO and RuOx-Y-LDO. These results demonstrate that the acid sites measured by NH3-TPD (Fig. S2) on RuO2-LDO and RuOx-Y-LDO are mainly Lewis acid sites, and the Y addition is further helpful to enhance the content of Lewis acid sites. Fig. 4 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the RuOx-REE-LDO samples. Compared to RuO2-LDO, all modified catalysts lose a reduction peak of free RuO2 around 160 °C. Moreover, the samples of RuOx-REE-LDO catalysts exhibit one broad reduction peak at 400–700 °C, which can be assigned to the reduction of well-dispersed RuOx that interacted strongly with the support [57,58]. As shown in Fig. 4, the reduction temperature shifted to higher values after the introduction of rare earth elements. In RuOx-Y-LDO, reduction temperature of Ru-O-Mg(Al) reached 700 °C, indicating a stronger Strong Metal-Support Interaction (SMSI) effect in RuOx-Y-LDO [59,60]. In order to understand the role of rare earth elements in promoting the activity of Ru, XPS analysis was performed on the catalysts ( Fig. 5). In the Ru 3d XPS spectra, a dominant peak at a binding energy (BE) of 284.6 eV and two minor peaks at BE of 281.7 eV and 280.0 eV are observed in the RuOx-LDO sample, which can be ascribed to Ru 3d3/2 overlapped with C 1s, Ru 3d5/2(Ru4+) and Ru 3d5/2(Ru0) respectively. The Ru-REE-LDO samples have a higher Ru4+/Ru0 ratio than that of RuO2-LDO (Table S2), and RuOx-Y-LDO has the highest Ru4+/Ru0 ratio. This result is in agreement with the H2-TPR results. The XPS results indicated that the introduction of rare earth elements significantly promoted the oxidation ability of Ru species. Moreover, the Ru4+ species in both the Ru-REE-LDO present a positive shift compared to that in RuO2-LDO. Furthermore, the SMSI interaction between the catalyst support and Ru metal can significantly increase the binding energy of Ru atoms because of the formation of Ru-O-Mg bond [61]. The high oxidation state is due to the higher valence of Ru compounds or smaller RuO2 particle size. According to the H2-TPR results, the rare earth elements doping can not only reduce the RuO2 particle size, but also enhance the interaction between Ru and carrier and thus increase the electron conduction rate in the catalyst [62]. 3.2 The performance of catalysts 3.2.1 Isomerization of LA to CLA To ensure the rare earth modified Ru dropped LDO composite could promote both isomerization reaction and Diels-Alder reaction, the isomerization of linoleic acid over RuOx-REE-LDO was first investigated. As shown in Table 2, La, Y and Ce modified RuOx doped LDO catalysts could participated in this reaction. The activity depended strongly on the rare earth, the RuOx-La-LDO and RuOx-Y-LDO showed better catalytic activity (Table 2, entries 7 and 9) than pure RuO2-LDO (Table 2, entry 6), while RuOx-Ce-LDO exhibited low yield (Table 2, entry 8). These results were consistent with the above CO2-TPD and H2-TPR results, confirming that the stronger basicity and SMSI effect of the catalyst can indeed improve the performance of the catalyst. Moreover, compared with the previous reported Ru-based isomerization catalysts such as Ru/ USY, Ru/Al2O3, Ru/C, Ru/MWCNTs, Ru-Ba-MgZrO (Table 2, entries 1–4), RuOx-Y-LDO showed the highest yield of CLA, which is similar with that of Ru @Ba-MgZrO (Table 2, entry 5). The influence of Y and Ru content was further investigated. It is clearly that increasing the Y loading amount could significantly increase the LCA yield (Table 2, entries 9–11), when the catalyst RuOx(1.5 %)-LDO doped with 3 % Y exhibits the highest catalytic activity (Table 2, entry 9). Further raising the Y loading amount did not give better result (Table 2, entry 12). The possible reason is that appropriate amount of Y can improve the alkalinity of the catalyst to a limited extent, but the excessive Y may destroy the crystal structure. The effect of Ru loading on isomerization was also investigated. The results showed that 1.5 % of Ru is the best choice, showing high catalytic activity (Table 2, entries 9 and 14–16). Therefore, RuOx(1.5 %)-Y(3 %)-LDO was chosen as the best composite catalyst. However, when using methyl linoleate was used instead of linoleic acid in the standard isomerization condition, no reaction occurred (Table 2, entry 17), perhaps due to that ester group cannot be adsorbed on the alkaline site of the catalyst. This result also explained that stronger basic site densities is conducive to the isomerization reaction. In addition, the distribution of the catalytic products of the Ru-Y-LDO was showed in fig. S4. As we can see, the content of the three isomers is confirmed by comparison: cis-9, trans-11-CLA (22 %), trans-10, cis-12-CLA (19 %) and trans-9, trans-11-CLA (42.6 %). 3.2.2 Diels-Alder reaction performance Then, the reactivity of RuOx-REE-LDO for the Diels-Alder reaction of CLA has been tested. As shown in the Table 3, the thermal promoted Diels-Alder reaction gave 52 % yield within 6 h under 180 ℃ (Table 3 entry 1). While the pure RuO2-LDO could slightly promoted the Diels-Alder reaction, about 58 % yield of C22-CSA was obtained (Table 3 entry 3). All of the three kinds of RuOx-REE-LDO could significantly improve the reaction efficiency (Table 3 entries 4–6), and RuOx-Y-LDO showed the highest CLA yield of 74 % with a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 77. Although, 86 % yield of desired product was obtained when using Sc(OTf)3 as the catalyst under a milder reaction condition, only a very low TOF of 0.34 was obtained (Table 3 entry 2) [40]. 3.2.3 One-pot sequential isomerization/maleinisation of linoleic acid Based on the above results, we studied the influence of various catalyst parameters on the catalytic activity for the one-pot maleization of linoleic acid under solvent-free conditions. As shown in Table 4, all of the four Ru doped LDO catalysts could participated in this reaction (Table 4, entries 3–6). The rare earth La and Y modified RuOx-LDO is better than pure RuO2-LDO, and RuOx-Y-LDO exhibits the highest yield. The Ru loading of the catalyst has a great influence on the yield of C22- As can be seen in Fig. 6a, the yield was increased with the increasing of Ru loading amount. The best result was achieved when 1.5 % Ru was loaded. The amount of catalyst also affected the catalytic performance. For RuOx-Y-LDO, increasing the Y amount from 1 % to 3 % leads to a gradual increase in C22-CSA yield from 74 % to 93 % (Fig. 6b). Different molar ratios also highly inﬂuenced the reaction results (Fig. 6c). Raising the molar ratio of maleic anhydride could increase the yield of C22-CSA (Fig. 6d), when the ratio of MA/LA was 3, the C22-CSA yield reached 93 % and further increasing the amount of maleic anhydride has no obvious effect. Furthermore, the effect of reaction time on the maleization of linoleic acid was also investigated. As displayed in Fig. 6e, during the early period of the reaction, the C22-CSA yields gradually enhanced with the increase of the reaction time. The C22-CSA yield reached the maximum at the reaction time of 10 h, and then keeped almost unchanged with further prolonging the reaction time. Finally, the reaction temperature has been also invested, as seen in Fig. 6f. Once increasing the reaction temperature from 140° to 160°C, the yields of C22-CSA gradually enhanced. On further increasing the reaction temperature from 160° to 180°C, the yield did not change significantly, but the yields gradually declined when the temperature reached to 200 °C. Thus, the optimal reaction temperature was 180 °C. The results of different method are listed in Table 4. Compared with I2 and RuO2-LDO, the RuOx-Y-LDO gave the highest yield and TOF value over the 6 synthesis methods (Table 4, entries 1, 3 and 6). Although Rh(OAc)2 catalyzed maleinisation of oleic acid could give a satisfactory yield with low reaction temperature, the homogneous catalyst is difficult to be reused and the TOF is very low (Table 4, entry 2). No doubt, methyl linoleate were still inert under the present cascade reaction (Table 4, entry 7), which confirmed that the adsorption of carboxyl group at the basic site of catalyst is the key to start the reaction. To demonstrate the stability and reusability of the rare earth modified Ru doped LDO catalysts, RuOx-Y-LDO was recycled multiple times under the optimized one-pot maleization of linoleic acid reaction conditions. On completion of each reaction, RuOx-Y-LDO was recovered using a centrifuge, washed with ethanol three times, dried at 80 °C, and then reused for the next reaction with a fresh batch. The recycling tests are shown in Fig. 7. Obviously, RuOx-Y-LDO still showed great performance for the preparation of C22-CSA after being reused 20 times. Furthermore, no significant changes in the morphology were observed with XRD (Fig. S7) and FT-IR (Fig. S8) after recovering the catalyst. Based on the above facts and previous reports, a plausible mechanism for the direct maleinisation of linoleic acid to C22-CSA is proposed in Scheme 3. Initially, the carboxyl group of linoleic acid was adsorbed to the basic site of the catalyst, then the strong basicity site captured allyl-H of γ-carbon to form carboanion 1. Next the ion of carboanion 1 interacted with RuOx to form a complex 2, which leads to double bond migration [34]. The ruthenium with higher oxidation state favours double-bond isomerization [18]. Then the hydrogen migrated from the allyl-H shifted from the basicity sites to RuOx due to SMSI. Subsequent migration of the hydrogen to the γ-carbon atom to generate CLA 3. Afterwards, the trans-double bond of CLA was transformed into cis configuration prone to Diels-Alder reaction by thermal. Thus, The CLA intermediate isomers are not important for the prepare the final product C22-CSA. Meanwhile, as a lewis acid site in the catalyst, Y2O3 adsorbed the carbonylic oxygen of maleic anhydride and promoted the Diels-Alder reaction [63]. Finally, the dissociation of active catalyst species from complex 5 inresults the formation of C22-CSA. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of novel rare earth elements modified Ru dropped LDO dual catalysts were successfully prepared using a conventional one-pot hydrothermal method. Compared with RuO2-LDO catalyst, the obtained composite RuOx-Y-LDO catalysts exhibited dramatic enhanced catalytic activities for both isomerization reaction of linoleic acid to CLA, and Diels-Alder reaction between CLA and maleic anhydride, so as to generated C22-CSA in on-pot successfully. The increased activities should be ascribed to the promotional synergistic effect of rare earth Y and the strong interactions among the composites as demonstrated by the various characterizations. Detailedly, the CO2-TPD analysis revealed that the superior catalytic performance was attributed to the stronger basic site densities. The pyridine-adsorbed IR spectra provide direct evidence for the Lewis acid sites identifcation. XPS and H2-TPR analysis confirmed that the strong interactions among the catalysts and the great changes of chemical composition resulting from the introduction of Y. All these advantages endow the catalyst with outstanding catalytic performance with 93 % yield of C22-CSA and 60 mol (LA) mol−1 (Ru) h−1 TOF value under solvent-free condition, higher than most of the previous published works. Finally, its remarkable reusability also provided a great application potential in industrial catalysis. coredata.dc:description: A series of rare earth elements (Y, La, and Ce) modified Ru doped MgAl-layered double oxides (LDO) have been prepared and applied in direct maleinisation of linoleic acid. The as-obtained catalysts can promote both isomerization reaction and Diels-Alder reaction in one-pot to generate 22-carbon cyclic succinic anhydrides (C22-CSA) efficiently. Among the surveyed LDO, Y modified Ru doped LDO (RuOx-Y-LDO) showed the best yield (93 %) and the turnover frequency (TOF) is higher than that of previously reported catalysts. Characterizations and control experiments verified that Y elements endow the LDO with stronger basic site densities to chelate with carboxyl group of oleic acid, resulted in smaller particle size of Ru and strong Ru-support interaction to isomerization of linoleic acid. The Y cation in RuOx-LDO could rich Lewis acid and significantly promoted the Diels-Alder reaction. Furthermore, RuOx-Y-LDO catalyst could be used up to 20 times without a significant loss in its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Rare earth modified RuOx-MgAl-layered double oxides as efficient dual catalysts for direct maleinisation of linoleic acid
